text:
When
#Bitcoin
reached $1, it was then bound to reach $10.  Once it reached $10, then $100, then $1k, it was certain to reach $10k, then $100k.  

Now people wonder if it will ever reach $1m, and then eventually $10m.

Bitcoin is a deterministic rocket. 

The bigger it gets, the more people it reaches, the more certain it will go higher in time.

text:
Oregon had a halving schedule.

In the early 1840s, 640 acres of prime farmland were granted to each couple who arrived via the Oregon Trail.  One square mile.

In 1850, this was decreased to 320 acres.

In 1862, this was decreased to 160 acres.

The earlier a new adopter made the journey, the better off they were.

But of course, the earlier you went, the more dangerous and challenging the journey was.

The earliest migrants attempted the journey before the Oregon Trail was navigable by covered wagon.

In 1839, 18 men set out from Illinois with a flag emblazoned with their motto ‚ÄúOregon or the Grave.‚Äù  Half of these men made it to the fertile land of Oregon; half died on the journey.

Each year after, more attempted the journey.  Such was the promise of a new life, and ample farmland in Oregon.

‚ÄúThe Great Migration of 1843‚Äù brought 1,000 new settlers via wagon train.

Imagine how late those families felt.  All the very best farmland was taken.  

Instead of 640 acres right next to the Willamette River, you might have to settle for an equally fertile plot one mile away!

Of course, we can recognize that complaint as ridiculous.  It‚Äôs obvious to us that anyone in the first few thousand settlers of Oregon was extremely early.

And guess what‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs effectively where we‚Äôre at with Bitcoin.

Everyone who arrives at the Bitcoin thesis feels late.  Everyone wishes they had stacked sats earlier.

But it‚Äôs better to remember how many people are still behind us.  

Bitcoin isn‚Äôt a small region like Oregon.  Bitcoin is for everyone - it is digital capital that could grow to be 50% of all the world‚Äôs asset value, according to Saylor.

And yet, maybe 10M people on Earth understand Bitcoin as an important savings vehicle.  That‚Äôs ~0.1% of the world.

So if you‚Äôre arriving now, you‚Äôre in the first 0.2% of genuine adopters.  That means 99.8% of the world is still behind you.  And they‚Äôre on their way.

You may not feel like you‚Äôre early to Oregon‚Ä¶ but you are.

Make the most of this opportunity and your descendants will know you as the legend who changed everything for your family.

text:
There's another side of corporate adoption of
#Bitcoin
that we don't talk about enough. 

This is GoodOnya - the organic electrolyte powder.  

It's an awesome product, owned and operated by one of my oldest friends and his design dynamo wife, and they're growing like crazy.

(Check them out on Amazon, highly recommend.  They didn't ask me to write this, which is why I am.)

But what's relevant here is that they're using Bitcoin as part of their treasury strategy.

For small businesses, using Bitcoin as a treasury asset provides a unique competitive advantage.

Bitcoin is for everyone.  And that means it benefits every type of entity.

Individuals.  Investment funds.  Public companies.  Governments.  These are the visible ones we hear about.

But small businesses benefit from Bitcoin just as much, if not more than these other groups.  

Just ask
@TheRealTahinis
(they originally inspired Strategy's bitcoin treasury move) who have used Bitcoin to grow to more than 60 restaurant locations in a short space of time.

As Bitcoin continues to prove itself a valuable ally for small businesses, it will increasingly become the norm for operators to keep assets in Bitcoin.  

And that will only further normalize Bitcoin as part of the fabric of the financial landscape.

Until then, small businesses like GoodOnya, Tahini's, and thousands of others will quietly have an edge thanks to Bitcoin.

Bitcoin is for everyone.  And every balance sheet.

text:
Did I crack one of humanity's enduring mysteries?

Here's a quick video recap & my questions for you...

Note:  full article at link in bio, or onceinaspecies (dot) com!

engagement.note: These figures were correct as of January 27, 2026, 12:00 PM London time

text:
Valuing scarcity is what differentiates us as a species, what makes us human.

Which means
#Bitcoin
is the fulfilment of our species-long quest for better scarcity.

This only happens Once-in-a-Species.

engagement.note: These figures were correct as of January 27, 2026, 12:00 PM London time

text:
And now, Bitcoin perfected scarcity.

For the first time in history, we have an asset that is immutably finite ‚Äî absolutely scarce.

We are witnessing the inevitable gravitation of our species to the perfection of store-of-value scarcity.

It's in our DNA.

engagement.note: These figures were correct as of January 27, 2026, 12:00 PM London time

text:
So where does Bitcoin come in?

If you zoom out far enough, the history of money is a long process of upgrading from one form of money to a fitter, more scarce form of money.

Monetary Darwinism.

Shells ‚Üí glass beads ‚Üí gold ‚Üí ?

engagement.note: These figures were correct as of January 27, 2026, 12:00 PM London time

text:
In short, humanity‚Äôs triumph is likely due to a single mutation 300,000 - 160,000 years ago.  This..

1. Supercharged our brain centers for abstract thought
2. Enabled us to develop the concept of money
3. Led to our overpowering advantage of multi-tribe population coordination

engagement.note: These figures were correct as of January 27, 2026, 12:00 PM London time

text:
And that's what the archaeological evidence shows.

We weren‚Äôt stronger or smarter.  We didn‚Äôt have better tools.

We had money ‚Äî and it allowed us to coordinate large populations to outcompete other early human groups.

engagement.note: These figures were correct as of January 27, 2026, 12:00 PM London time

text:
With money...

You gain a constructive transactional medium, a new option alongside time-honored violence.

You unlock peaceful inter-tribal trade.
You unlock inter-tribal alliances.

You can coordinate multi-tribe populations, 10x larger than solitary Neanderthal tribes.

engagement.note: These figures were correct as of January 27, 2026, 12:00 PM London time

text:
Once you have money, something profound becomes possible:

Scaling human cooperation beyond the tribe. 

Beyond Dunbar's number of 150 individuals.

engagement.note: These figures were correct as of January 27, 2026, 12:00 PM London time

text:
Neanderthals may have engaged in occasional symbolic behavior (art, collectibles, etc)

But our species was compelled to engage in these behaviors on a massive scale.

We coveted scarce collectibles enough to bootstrap the concept of money.  Shell money.

And that was the key...

engagement.note: These figures were correct as of January 27, 2026, 12:00 PM London time

text:
This mutated protein causes greater neurogenesis in the outermost layers of the frontal lobe...

The part of the brain responsible for abstract thought.

In other words, this mutation over-developed the brain circuitry for abstract thinking.

engagement.note: These figures were correct as of January 27, 2026, 12:00 PM London time

text:
A recent discovery in Neuroscience provides the key.

In 2022, Pinson et al. published their findings on a gene mutation in TKTL1. 

All modern humans have the mutated version, Neanderthals and other early humans don't.

engagement.note: These figures were correct as of January 27, 2026, 12:00 PM London time

text:
The Austrians further outlined the process by which a scarce commodity (like seashells) can gain the properties of money.

First, it must be valued ‚Äî coveted ‚Äî by a small portion of the group as a collectible.

But what causes this?  Why do we value scarce collectibles at all?

engagement.note: These figures were correct as of January 27, 2026, 12:00 PM London time

text:
Anthropology continues to interpret shell beads as evidence that early humans cared about looking good.

Using Austrian econ, Szabo demonstrated in "Shelling Out" that these shell beads served an economic purpose.

A form of proto-money.  Shell money.

engagement.note: These figures were correct as of January 27, 2026, 12:00 PM London time

text:
When Szabo wrote "Shelling Out" in 2002, the oldest known example of this behavior was 75,000 years old.

Since then, we've discovered shell bead jewelry 82k, 100k, 120k years old.

In 2021, these shell beads from a cave in Morocco were dated to 142,000 years old.

engagement.note: These figures were correct as of January 27, 2026, 12:00 PM London time

text:
The answer may lie not in what Neanderthals did‚Ä¶ but in what they didn‚Äôt do.

And it starts with a behavior so seemingly trivial, it‚Äôs often overlooked.

We collected seashells and fashioned them into jewelry... Neanderthals essentially did not.

engagement.note: These figures were correct as of January 27, 2026, 12:00 PM London time

text:
They even engaged in art.

In 2024, this cave art from Spain was dated to 66,000 years ago...  20,000 years before our species arrived in Europe. 

Meaning, these hands belong to a Neanderthal.

So what was the difference between our species?  What was our edge?

engagement.note: These figures were correct as of January 27, 2026, 12:00 PM London time

text:
For over a hundred years, the answer was that we must have been better, smarter, more evolved.

But that doesn't fit with the evidence.

According to expert
@ChrisStringer65
, Neanderthals had similar tools, weapons, language, and brains.

They were like us.

engagement.note: These figures were correct as of January 27, 2026, 12:00 PM London time

text:
For millions of years, a handful of early human species coexisted on Earth.

Then, in the blink of evolutionary time, one took over.

Why did Homo sapiens sapiens (that's us) triumph over the Neanderthals and others?

engagement.note: These figures were correct as of January 27, 2026, 12:00 PM London time

text:
A single mutation in your DNA may explain why you exist‚Ä¶ and it might explain
#Bitcoin
too.

A THREAD on...

Neanderthals, cave art, seashells, and our 300,000-year obsession with scarcity.

text:
This timeline summarizes humanity's entire history and the development of monetary technology.

You may notice that something special happened between 300,000 and 160,000 years ago.

This gave our species the capacity to develop the concept of money.  And this proved to be our edge.  

It also explains the inescapable gravity of Bitcoin...

In the last week, 21,000 people have read "Once-in-a-Species" - my favorite piece I've ever written.  Thank you all for the overwhelmingly positive feedback!

For those yet to take the ride, it's a 14-minute read, link in bio!
